critique: This executive order establishes a special assistant to the Attorney General to investigate potential misconduct within the federal government. It mandates cooperation from all executive departments and agencies, ensuring access to information and personnel. The order is temporary, expiring at the end of 1952. It seems to be focused on ensuring accountability and preventing corruption within the government. There is nothing explicitly ideological about this order. It does not seem to touch on immigration. It expands executive power by creating this role. It does not seem to touch on federalism. It prioritizes national security by attempting to root out corruption. It does not seem to touch on economic regulation. It does not seem to touch on social inclusion.
